Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Assessing Functional Diversity of Algal Communities at the Single Cell Level with a Compact Multi-function Microfluidic Cytometer
Award.AbstractNarration: Photosynthetic microalgae are dominant primary food producers in aquatic systems, and algal mass culture has a strong potential to produce oil-based fuel and to remove carbon dioxide from the atmosphere. However, algal production of foods/oils fluctuates strongly, and the reasons for this are unknown since information on individual algal cells under natural conditions is currently inaccessible. This need is addressed here with novel technology (a custom-designed, multifunction, ultra-compact cytometer) able to simultaneously assess the efficiency with which individual algal cells utilize solar energy for photosynthesis and their oil content. In light of the critical importance of microbes for human health, energy needs, and ecosystem sustainability ? and in the absence of established technology for the characterization of microbial functional diversity ? this research addresses an urgent need. Specifically, this research will (i) first confirm proper cytometer performance with laboratory-grown algal cultures, (ii) add further monitoring parameters needed to differentiate individual algal cells in mixed natural communities, and (iii) assess the functional diversity of algae in these communities in Colorado lakes. The results of this study are expected to allow a better prediction of toxic algal blooms and repercussions of changes in microbial oil content throughout food chains as well as identification of algae with superior properties for biofuels production. This highly diverse collaborative team of researchers includes an ecologist, a biophysicist, and photobiologists, thus providing not only the necessary intersection of novel technology and ecological expertise, but also providing an interdisciplinary educational opportunity for students, especially for training in biology (algal physiology and ecology) of students with a background in math, physics, or engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Photosynthetic microbes, such as single-celled algae and bacteria, are major drivers of both natural and commercial services of aquatic ecosystems. In addition, mass culture of algae/bacteria has a strong potential to produce energy carriers usable as fuels and/or high-value chemicals and to sequester atmospheric CO2. The causes of strong fluctuations in the productivity of photosynthetic microbes, however, are unknown since functional information on individual microbial cells under natural conditions is currently inaccessible. The goal of the project was to develop technology capable of assessing the productivity of single cells in mixed natural and commercial microbial communities to address this need. We designed a novel, compact instrument consisting of robust components (with a high potential for adaptation into a field-portable version) and capable of simultaneously, ultra-rapidly, and non-destructively identifying microbial species, their efficiency of solar-energy capture, and their accumulation of valuable products. During the funding period, we designed a prototype and demonstrated instrument performance (identification and characterization of different groups of photosynthetic microbes) for mixed cultures of photosynthetic microbes. In addition, we substantially reconceived and redesigned our prototype instrument to adapt a particular technique (pulse-amplitude-modulated chlorophyll fluorescence) to operate with unprecedented rapidity and sensitivity enabling us to quantify solar-energy conversion efficiency of single microbial cells not only under experimental low-light conditions (as done by our prototype), but also under conditions of full sunlight, which is critical for the evaluation of natural communities and commercial mass culture.
